subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking
Allowed. Conversations on the leading edge
of knowledge and discovery with
parapsychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello, and welcome. I’m Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today once again
I'll be returning to the big
list of questions left by viewers of our
October 11th
Live Stream event. I'll
get right into it now. Melissa Urban says,
“Would you be willing to offer an
internship?
I have a visual mixed media degree and
have so many questions for so many things
you've discussed on your channel.”
Melissa, we welcome volunteers. We don't
have a budget to pay
for employees or interns at the moment.
It would be great if we did.
But if for those of you watching, if
you're interested in volunteering
let me encourage you to send an email to
friends@newthinkingallowed.com.
I actually read those emails myself and
if you're interested in volunteering we
can use people to
transcribe our interviews and monologues,
to translate them into foreign languages, to
help us with our
publicity, there are many other editing
tasks, grant writing so that we can afford at
some point to
hire people, working on our
website. You know, this is actually
a rather large operation and it's mostly
all on my shoulders. So
I do welcome assistance from viewers.
We actually have over 300 volunteers.
They come and they go because
they're volunteers but I'm very grateful
for the enormous amount of
help that I have received. It's been a
godsend.
Forever Conscious Research channel
says, “New Thinking Allowed with Jeffrey
Mishlove,
thank you for all your hard work. I'm
curious how someone of your
intellect could still believe in
politics and the system
in general. Both sides are criminals.”
Well, thank you for your compliments.
It's not about intellect, I suppose ,that
it causes me to have faith in the system.
It's more
at the emotional level. It's about trust.
I basically have faith in humanity.
I basically think that people at
bottom, it's not as if we don't
have lots of
criminal elements amongst us, but I think
even amongst criminals
and I worked with murderers and rapists
at San Quentin
prison. They're mostly good people most
of the time,
even criminals. So, I do have faith in the
system. And I'll tell you, what I disagree with is that both
sides are criminals. No.
There are criminals who are involved in
the system at all levels of politics and
business, of course there are. But you
know what,
it's those very criminals who want you
to believe that everybody is a criminal,
people who push that notion that they're
all criminals know
there are many well-intentioned people
working in the media, working in government,
working in medicine and in science,
in our institutions. I mean, think about
it, do you expect that you could live the
life that you're
living right now and have water and
electricity
and internet service if there weren't
thousands or even millions, millions of
good people
working every day to make that happen
for you?
So, I don't buy into that cynicism and I
don't think that I'm being namby panty
about it either. I'm not
blind to the negative
influences in our culture.
Amy Slabaugh says,
“I am deeply impressed by your commitment
to consciousness
research. How do you stay so motivated
and passionate?
Do you feel your motivation is
influenced by…”
and then she leaves it blank.
Well, it is true. I do feel motivated and
passionate about this field. I am of the
opinion that human beings
have so much potential,
there's so much good that we can yet
accomplish.
One of my mentors, Jean Houston used
to say, “Put it this way. We are given a
Stradivarius violin but we only learned
to play it like a plastic
fiddle.” I think what she meant by
that is our mind-body
system. We have so much potential in our
bodies, our nervous system, our awareness.
It gets me very, very excited. But let me
say this. I'm a fortunate person, I realize that.
I was born under good circumstances in a
good year to a good
family. I've always had good mentors and
friends and
people encouraging me to become the
person who I've
become. That's why I guess I
want to pass it on. I want to pay it
forward. I want to encourage
others as well. I get so
high from sharing my
exuberance for the field of
consciousness and parapsychology.
It's my great joy. It's what keeps me
going. But maybe as a previous questioner
once suggested, I don't even have any
free will.
It's just something that bubbles
out of me. I
don't know how else to explain it at
times. Johann Hemberg asks,
“Have you seen a larger interest
in parapsychology in the last 10
years?” Larger. That's an interesting question
because the interest in parapsychology
was actually very large when I got into the
field back in the 1970s. That's when
the remote viewing research was first
coming out and Uri Geller became
an internationally known psychic
who had a huge impact. But
he's asking about the last ten years. For
the last five years I've been doing the New Thinking Allowed channel.
I think we've been having an impact.
Also, I can say I believe the interest
is growing
in the United Kingdom where there are
now many
colleges and universities where
professors are
guiding people to study this field.
We have so, so very much more to do.
So I cannot say that I feel encouraged,
especially in the United States yet.
Research funding has not to my knowledge
really increased
in the last ten years.
Carol Johnson says, “After reading
Many Lives, Many Masters I am intrigued
and may try to experience a past life
regression. Have you done so, Jeff? How did
your experience
feel or affect you?” Well,
Carol, actually I used to practice
past life regression therapy back
in the days when I lived in California
and I was a
licensed psychotherapist. But I became
a little bit disillusioned with it. Just,
I say a little bit. The
part that disillusioned me is that the
imagery that people came up with under
past life regression hypnosis
was an authentic past life. I found many
times I simply
couldn't confirm it, most of the time. Now,
I think that imagery is valid because...
Not valid necessarily for evidence of
reincarnation but
valid as an emotional expression,
a symbolic expression. You could call
it a narrative that expresses
emotionally
what is going on with the individual
who's having that experience,
just like if it were a dream as a matter
of fact. So I do feel like regression
therapy is useful and valid but not
for the point of view of establishing
past lives. Now,
yes, I have been regressed many times
as a matter of fact.
To be honest, I don't place
much stock in the imagery that comes up
under hypnotic regression as
convincing me that those represent my
own past lives. If you're interested in
exploring your past lives it can be
useful and I think there are
examples where people under regression
did uncover information that was later
validated but those examples
are less common than you might imagine.
They represent probably only a small
percentage of
actual regressions. I can tell you
this for what it's worth.
The people who are doing the most
extensive research
on past lives at the University of Virginia
where they're looking at the past life
memories of young
children who start describing past lives
almost as soon as they can talk,
those people have a rather
dim view of past life regression
therapy as being evidential.
Phillip Bernhardt-House, who has been a
guest on
New Thinking Allowed,
asks, “Is there a difference between
‘all is one’ and ‘all is
connected?’ If so, what is it? If not,
why not? And if not, can
‘all is one’ be a tautology that covers
too much?” Well, very good questions
and probably much
more than I could answer
briefly. Let me try and
give you the short answer and that is
whether you say “all is one” or whether
you say “all is interconnected” or connected
probably depends
on the perspective from which you're
looking
at the world. It might be
like talking about a country like the
United States. You could say, yes, we're
all Americans. Or you could say,
well, we're all connected to each other
because we're part of
this larger system we call the United
States. To me it's sort of a question of
semantics. Peter Pipe asks, “When
will science and spirituality merge
to become super science?”
Great question. I've referred
earlier, I believe, to the writings of
the great sociologist Pitirim
A. Sorokin. This was his goal
in a sense. He called this the idealistic
society when we have
an external sensate view of the world
and an internal, he called it an ideational view
of the world and they come together in a
perfect balance. He said this is very
rare. He says it has happened
historically. It happened
at the height of ancient Greek culture.
It happened at the height of the Renaissance culture.
I know Sorokin was very hopeful
that it will happen again,
that much of the discontent and
disillusionment
that we are experiencing right now in
our society
is the result of the the materialistic
paradigm, or as Sorokin would call it,
the sensate
paradigm of our culture is breaking down.
It's not satisfying people. We know we're
so much larger than that. But to forge a true
synthesis is not a simple matter. After all
what you get, as Sorokan points out, are
syncretisms,
premature attempts to merge these
two that don't really hold together.
There's another risk
that Sorokin points out at least in
Western culture,
these moments of merging of science and
spirituality are short-lived. The height of the
Renaissance
and the height of the Greek culture in
Athens didn't last
really more than probably less than
100 years.
In Asian culture he sees it
lasting longer. He believes the ancient
Egyptians had
such a culture for themselves that
lasted for thousands of years.
The Chinese had a balanced culture
Sorokin claims lasted for centuries.
So it could happen
soon. I would say
a good probability, we'll see such a
culture in the next hundred years.
I think before I close I want to remind
you that you can subscribe to our free
weekly newsletter by going to the New
Thinking Allowed Foundation
website. That's new thinking allowed, one
word, allowed is spelled a-l-l-o-w-e-d
dot o-r-g. You can subscribe there to our
free weekly newsletter.
You can also check out our searchable
database. It includes not only our own
videos but
several videos from other YouTube channels.
All you have to do is put a search
term, any search term in,
it'll take you to the very spot in the
videos where that search term
is discussed. So check it out
and do subscribe to our weekly
newsletter.
Before I go let me leave you
with this question from Phillip Bernhardt-House:
Do you accept the idea that all is one,
the great thought that mystics
throughout history and in every culture
have articulated?
How does that ring to you, all is one or
conversely all is connected? How do you
feel about that?
Thank you for being with me.
[Music]
